introduction.description: The Grade 12 Physics curriculum builds on Grade 11, covering advanced topics in mechanics, thermodynamics, waves and optics, electricity and magnetism, modern physics, and emerging physics, preparing students for applications like satellite technology, medical imaging, and nanotechnology.

objectives.description: Apply advanced physics principles to analyze complex systems in mechanics, thermodynamics, and modern physics.
Solve practical problems using concepts like electromagnetic induction and nuclear physics.
Conduct experiments to verify physical laws, such as heat engine efficiency or wave properties.
Integrate physics with environmental care, social values, and ethical considerations.
Develop models to demonstrate advanced concepts, like capacitors or quantum phenomena.

topics.description: Surface tension: Theory of surface tension; Surface energy
topics.elaboration: Explain surface tension and surface energy, with applications in capillary action for plant water transport.
Define and calculate centripetal force for systems like satellites in orbit or vehicles on curved roads.

topics.description: State and explain second law of thermodynamics (Kelvin’s and Clausius’ statements)
topics.elaboration: Apply the second law to heat engines and refrigerators, analyzing efficiency in power plants.

topics.description: Solve mathematical problems related to heat engine
topics.elaboration: Calculate efficiency and work output of heat engines, such as in car engines or thermal power plants.

topics.description: Explain molecules, intermolecular forces, and derive ideal gas equation
topics.elaboration: Derive PV=nRT and explain molecular interactions in gases, applicable to weather modeling.

topics.description: Average translational kinetic energy of gas molecule
topics.elaboration: Calculate kinetic energy of gas molecules, relevant to temperature scales in meteorology.

topics.description: Boltzmann constant, root mean square speed
topics.elaboration: Use Boltzmann constant to compute RMS speed, applied in gas diffusion studies.
Analyze heat capacities for gases and solids, used in material science for thermal design.
Study light as an electromagnetic wave, with applications in optical communication.

topics.description: Huygen’s principle to explain reflection and refraction of light
topics.elaboration: Use Huygen’s principle to model wave fronts in lens design and optical systems.
Analyze lens aberrations and their correction in telescopes and microscopes.
Design achromatic lenses for clear imaging in cameras and optical instruments.
Study thermoelectric effects for applications in cooling systems.
Explain magnetic hysteresis in transformers and magnetic storage devices.
Classify magnetic materials and their uses in motors and MRI machines.

topics.description: Discuss power in AC circuits and know the term power factor
topics.elaboration: Analyze power consumption in AC circuits, critical for electrical grid management.

topics.description: Parallel plate capacitor: Derive capacitance formula
topics.elaboration: Derive C=ε₀A/d and apply to capacitor design in electronics.
Derive equivalent resistance formulas and apply to circuit design.
Derive hf=φ+KE_max and apply to solar cells and photodetectors.
Analyze X-ray properties for medical imaging and crystallography.
Calculate radioactive decay parameters, used in carbon dating and nuclear medicine.
Explain the working of Geiger-Muller tubes for radiation detection.
Apply radioactive decay to determine the age of archaeological artifacts.
Explore applications like radiotherapy and PET scans in healthcare.

topics.description: Nuclear fission and fusion, energy released
topics.elaboration: Analyze energy release in nuclear reactions, critical for nuclear power plants.
Study detection and implications of gravitational waves, as observed by LIGO.
Explore nanoscale physics applications in electronics and medicine.
Understand the role of the Higgs Boson in particle physics and the Standard Model.

practical_activities.description: Study the variation of flame height with burner position
practical_activities.elaboration: Analyze flame dynamics to study combustion physics, relevant to engine design.

practical_activities.description: Study the status of hydroelectricity in Nepal
practical_activities.elaboration: Investigate hydroelectric power generation principles, like energy conversion efficiency.

practical_activities.description: Apply physics laws in a chosen context
practical_activities.elaboration: Demonstrate physics principles in real-world scenarios, e.g., nuclear physics in medical imaging.

components.elaboration: Assess engagement in discussions and collaborative learning activities.
Evaluate theoretical understanding through periodic written tests.
Assess experimental skills and project reports, emphasizing application.

external.description: Based on specification chart by Curriculum Development Centre, assessing knowledge, skills, and application through written exams.

methods: Group discussions (satellite learning group, peer group, small and large group)

assessment_approach.description: Explain how to measure a variable in an experiment
assessment_approach.elaboration: Assess measurement techniques, e.g., using a Geiger-Muller tube for radiation.

assessment_approach.description: Explain relationships between variables in an experiment
assessment_approach.elaboration: Evaluate variable interactions, like temperature vs. gas pressure.

assessment_approach.description: Value of constants or prediction with justification
assessment_approach.elaboration: Assess derivation of constants, e.g., Boltzmann constant.

assessment_approach.description: Handling of errors and precautions in experiments
assessment_approach.elaboration: Evaluate error analysis in experiments like X-ray measurements.
Assess verbal explanation of experimental procedures and results.

measurement_tools.use: Measure lengths and diameters, e.g., in surface tension experiments.
Measure curvature of surfaces, like lenses in optics experiments.
Measure small dimensions, e.g., wire thickness in electrical experiments.
Measure time intervals, e.g., in wave propagation experiments.
